Beyond Hypertree Width: Decomposition Methods Without Decompositions

Hubie Chen â€ƒâ€ƒ VÃ­ctor Dalmau
Abstract

The general intractability of the constraint satisfaction problem has motivated the study of restrictions on this problem that permit polynomial-time solvability. One major line of work has focused on structural restrictions, which arise from restricting the interaction among constraint scopes. In this paper, we engage in a mathematical investigation of generalized hypertree width, a structural measure that has up to recently eluded study. We obtain a number of computational results, including a simple proof of the tractability of CSP instances having bounded generalized hypertree width.

1 Introduction

The constraint satisfaction problem (CSP) is widely acknowledged as a convenient framework for modelling search problems. Instances of the CSP arise in a variety of domains, including artificial intelligence, database theory, algebra, propositional logic, and graph theory. An instance of the CSP consists of a set of constraints on a set of variables; the question is to determine if there is an assignment to the variables satisfying all of the constraints. Alternatively, the CSP can be cast as the fundamental algebraic problem of deciding, given two relational structures ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A and ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B, whether or not there is a homomorphism from ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A to ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B. In this formalization, each relation of ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A contains the tuples of variables that are constrained together, which are often called the constraint scopes, and the corresponding relation of ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B contains the allowable tuples of values that the variable tuples may take.

It is well-known that the CSP, in its general formulation, is NP-complete; this general intractability has motivated a large and rich body of research aimed at identifying and understanding restricted cases of the CSP that are polynomial-time tractable. The restrictions that have been studied can, by and large, be placed into one of two categories, whichâ€“due to the homomorphism formulation of the CSPâ€“have become known as left-hand side restrictions and right-hand side restrictions. From a high level view, left-hand side restrictions, also known as structural restrictions, arise from prespecifying a class of relational structures ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A from which the left-hand side structure ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A must come, while right-hand side restrictions arise from prespecifying a class of relational structures â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B from which the right-hand side structure ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B must come. As this paper is concerned principally with structural restrictions, we will not say more about right-hand side restrictions than that their systematic study has origins in a classic theorem of SchaeferÂ [21], and that recent years have seen some extremely exciting results on them (for instance [4, 5]).

The structural restrictions studied in the literature can all be phrased as restrictions on the hypergraph Hâ¢(ğ€)ğ»ğ€H(\mathbf{A})italic_H ( bold_A ) naturally arising from the left-hand side relational structure ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A, namely, the hypergraph Hâ¢(ğ€)ğ»ğ€H(\mathbf{A})italic_H ( bold_A ) with an edge {a1,â€¦,ak}subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{k}\}{ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } for each tuple (a1,â€¦,ak)subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k})( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A. Let us briefly review some of the relevant results that have been obtained on structural tractability. The tractability of left-hand side relational structures having bounded treewidth was shown in the constraint satisfaction literature by Dechter and Pearl [9] and Freuder [10].111 One way to define what we mean by treewidth here is the treewidth of the graph obtained from Hâ¢(ğ€)ğ»ğ€H(\mathbf{A})italic_H ( bold_A ) by drawing an edge between any two vertices that are in the same hyperedge. Later, Dalmau et al. [8] building on ideas of Kolaitis and Vardi [19, 20] gave a consistency-style algorithm for deciding the bounded treewidth CSP. For our present purposes, it is worth highlighting that although the notion of bounded treewidth is defined in terms of tree decompositions, which can be computed efficiently (under bounded treewidth), the algorithm given by Dalmau et al. [8] does not compute any form of tree decomposition. Dalmau et al. also identified a natural expansion of structures having bounded treewidth that is tractableâ€“namely, the structures homomorphically equivalent to those having bounded treewidth. The optimality of this latter result, in the case of bounded arity, was demonstrated by Grohe [15], who provedâ€“roughly speakingâ€“that if the tuples of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A are of bounded arity and ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A gives rise to a tractable case of the CSP, then it must fall into the natural expansion identified by Dalmau et al. [8].

A number of papers, including [17, 16, 13, 14, 11, 7], have studied restrictions that can be applied to relational structures of unbounded arity. (Note that any class of relational structures of unbounded arity cannot have bounded treewidth.) In a survey [13], Gottlob et al. show that the restriction of bounded hypertree widthÂ [11] is the most powerful structural restriction for the CSP in that every other structural restriction studied in the literature is subsumed by it. Since this work [11, 13], whether or not there is a more general structural restriction than bounded hypertree width that ensures tractability, has been a tantalizing open question.

In this paper, we study generalized hypertree width, a structural measure for hypergraphs defined in [12] that is a natural variation of hypertree width; we call this measure coverwidth. Coverwidth is trivially upper-bounded by hypertree width, and so any class of hypergraphs having bounded hypertree width has bounded coverwidth. We define a combinatorial pebble game that can be played on any CSP instance, and demonstrate that this game is intimately linked to coverwidth (TheoremÂ 3.2). Our study of coverwidth is conceptually simple, mathematically elegant, and relatively compact; we believe that this hints that coverwidth is in fact a natural and robust mathematical concept that may find further applications. Overall, the investigation we perform takes significant inspiration from methods, concepts, and ideas developed by Kolaitis, Vardi, and coauthors [19, 20, 8, 2] that link together CSP consistency algorithms, the existential kğ‘˜kitalic_k-pebble games of Kolaitis and Vardi [18], and bounded treewidth.

Using the pebble game perspective, we are able to derive a number of computational results. One is that the structural restriction of bounded coverwidth implies polynomial-time tractability; this result generalizes the tractability of bounded hypertree width. It has been independently shown by Adler et al. that the hypertree width of a hypergraph is linearly related to the coverwidthÂ [1]. This result can be used in conjunction with the tractability of bounded hypertree width to derive the tractability of bounded coverwidth. However, we believe our proof of bounded coverwidth tractability to be considerably simpler than the known proof of bounded hypertree width tractabilityÂ [11], even though our proof is of a more general result.

To describe our results in greater detail, it will be useful to identify two computational problems that every form of structural restriction gives rise to: a promise problem, and a no-promise problem. In both problems, the goal is to identify all CSP instances obeying the structural restriction as either satisfiable or unsatisfiable. In the promise problem, the input is a CSP instance that is guaranteed to obey the structural restriction, whereas in the no-promise problem, the input is an arbitrary CSP instance, and an algorithm may, on an instance not obeying the structural restriction, decline to identify the instance as satisfiable or unsatisfiable. Of course, CSPs arising in practice do not come with guarantees that they obey structural restrictions, and hence an algorithm solving the no-promise problem is clearly the more desirable. Notice that, for any structural restriction having a polynomial-time solvable promise problem, if it is possible to solve the identification problem of deciding whether or not an instance obeys the restriction, in polynomial time, then the no-promise problem is also polynomial-time solvable. For bounded hypertree width, both the identification problem and the no-promise problem are polynomial-time solvable. In fact, the survey by Gottlob et al. [13] only considers structural restrictions for which the identification problem is polynomial-time solvable, and thus only considers structural restrictions for which the no-promise problem is polynomial-time solvable.

One of our main theorems (TheoremÂ 4.3) is that the promise problem for bounded coverwidth is polynomial-time tractable, via a general consistency-like algorithm. In particular, we show that, on an instance having bounded coverwidth, our algorithm detects an inconsistency if and only if the instance is unsatisfiable. Our algorithm, like the consistency algorithm of Dalmau et al. [8] for bounded treewidth, can be applied to any CSP instance to obtain a more constrained instance; our algorithm does not need nor compute any form of decomposition, even though the notion of coverwidth is defined in terms of decompositions!

Intriguingly, we are then able to give a simple algorithm for the no-promise problem for bounded coverwidth (TheoremÂ 4.4) that employs the consistency-like algorithm for the promise problem. The behavior of this algorithm is reminiscent of self-reducibility arguments in computational complexity theory, and on an instance of bounded coverwidth, the algorithm is guaranteed to either report a satisfying assignment or that the instance is unsatisfiable. We believe that our results offer a direct challenge to the view of structural tractability advanced in the Gottlob et al. survey [13], since we are able to give a polynomial-time algorithm for the bounded coverwidth no-promise problem without explicitly showing that there is a polynomial-time algorithm for the bounded coverwidth identification problem.

Returning to the promise problem, we then show that the tractability of bounded coverwidth structures can be generalized to yield the tractability of structures homomorphically equivalent to those having bounded coverwidth (TheoremÂ 4.5). This expansion of bounded coverwidth tractability is analogous to the expansion of bounded treewidth tractability carried out in [8].

In the last section of this paper, we use the developed theory as well as ideas inÂ [6] to define a tractable class of quantified constraint satisfaction problems based on coverwidth.

We emphasize that none of the algorithms in this paper need or compute any type of decomposition, even though all of the structural restrictions that they address are defined in terms of decompositions.

Definitions.

In this paper, we formalize the CSP as a relational homomorphism problem. We review the relevant definitions that will be used. A relational signature is a finite set of relation symbols, each of which has an associated arity. A relational structure ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A (over signature Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ) consists of a universe Ağ´Aitalic_A and a relation Rğ€superscriptğ‘…ğ€R^{\mathbf{A}}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over Ağ´Aitalic_A for each relation symbol Rğ‘…Ritalic_R (of Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ), such that the arity of Rğ€superscriptğ‘…ğ€R^{\mathbf{A}}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT matches the arity associated to Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. We refer to the elements of the universe of a relational structure ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A as ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A-elements. When ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A is a relational structure over Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ and Rğ‘…Ritalic_R is any relation symbol of Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ, the elements of Rğ€superscriptğ‘…ğ€R^{\mathbf{A}}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are called ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A-tuples. Throughout this paper, we assume that all relational structures under discussion have a finite universe. We use boldface letters ğ€,ğ,â€¦ğ€ğâ€¦\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B},\ldotsbold_A , bold_B , â€¦ to denote relational structures.

A homomorphism from a relational structure ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A to another relational structure ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B is a mapping hâ„hitalic_h from the universe of ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A to the universe of ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B such that for every relation symbol Rğ‘…Ritalic_R and every tuple (a1,â€¦,ak)âˆˆRğ€subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘…ğ€(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k})\in R^{\mathbf{A}}( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, it holds that (hâ¢(a1),â€¦,hâ¢(ak))âˆˆRğâ„subscriptğ‘1â€¦â„subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘…ğ(h(a_{1}),\ldots,h(a_{k}))\in R^{\mathbf{B}}( italic_h ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , â€¦ , italic_h ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) âˆˆ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. (Here, kğ‘˜kitalic_k denotes the arity of Rğ‘…Ritalic_R.) The constraint satisfaction problem (CSP) is to decide, given an ordered pair ğ€,ğğ€ğ\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B of relational structures, whether or not there is a homomorphism from the first structure, ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A, to the second, ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B. A homomorphism from ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A to ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B in an instance ğ€,ğğ€ğ\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B of the CSP is also called a satisfying assignment, and when a satisfying assignment exists, we will say that the instance is satisfiable.

We measure a tree decomposition according to its heaviest bag, and define the coverwidth of a hypergraph according to the lightest-weight tree decomposition.

Definition 5

The weight of a tree decomposition of Hğ»Hitalic_H is the maximum weight over all of its bags.

Definition 6

The coverwidth of a hypergraph Hğ»Hitalic_H is the minimum weight over all tree decompositions of Hğ»Hitalic_H.

It is straightforward to verify that the coverwidth of a hypergraph is equal to the generalized hypertree width of a hypergraphÂ [12]. Since the generalized hypertree width of a hypergraph is always less than or equal to its hypertree width, coverwidth is at least as strong as hypertree width in that results on bounded coverwidth imply results on bounded hypertree width.

There is another formulation of tree decompositions that is often wieldy, see for instance [3].

It is well known that the property of having a perfect elimination ordering is equivalent to being chordal. The following proposition is also well-known.

Proposition 1

Let Hğ»Hitalic_H be a hypergraph. For every tree decomposition of Hğ»Hitalic_H, there exists a scheme such that each clique of the scheme is contained in a bag of the tree decomposition. Likewise, for every scheme of Hğ»Hitalic_H, there exists a tree decomposition such that each bag of the tree decomposition is contained in a clique of the scheme.

Let us define the weight of a scheme (of a hypergraph Hğ»Hitalic_H) to be the maximum weight (with respect to Hğ»Hitalic_H) over all of its cliques. The following proposition is immediate from Proposition 1 and the definition of coverwidth, and can be taken as an alternative definition of coverwidth.

Proposition 2

The coverwidth of a hypergraph Hğ»Hitalic_H is equal to the minimum weight over all schemes of Hğ»Hitalic_H.

We will often implicitly pass from a relational structure to its associated hypergraph, that is, we simply write ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A in place of Hâ¢(ğ€)ğ»ğ€H(\mathbf{A})italic_H ( bold_A ). In particular, we will speak of kğ‘˜kitalic_k-unions over a relational structure ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A.

3 Pebble Games

We now define a class of pebble games for studying the measure of coverwidth. These games are essentially equivalent to the existential kğ‘˜kitalic_k-pebble games defined by Kolaitis and Vardi and used to study constraint satisfactionÂ [18, 20]. The pebble game that we use is defined as follows. The game is played between two players, the Spoiler and the Duplicator, on a pair of relational structures ğ€,ğğ€ğ\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B that are defined over the same signature. Game play proceeds in rounds, and in each round one of the following occurs:

  1. 1.

    The Spoiler places a pebble on an ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A-element ağ‘aitalic_a. In this case, the Duplicator must respond by placing a corresponding pebble, denoted by hâ¢(a)â„ğ‘h(a)italic_h ( italic_a ), on a ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B-element.

  2. 2.

    The Spoiler removes a pebble from an ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A-element ağ‘aitalic_a. In this case, the corresponding pebble hâ¢(a)â„ğ‘h(a)italic_h ( italic_a ) on ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B is removed.

When game play begins, there are no pebbles on any ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A-elements, nor on any ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B-elements, and so the first round is of the first type. We assume that the Spoiler never places two pebbles on the same ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A-element, so that hâ„hitalic_h is a partial function (as opposed to a relation). The Duplicator wins the game if he can always ensure that hâ„hitalic_h is a projective homomorphism from ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A to ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B; otherwise, the Spoiler wins. A projective homomorphism (from ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A to ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B) is a partial function hâ„hitalic_h from the universe of ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A to the universe of ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B such that for any relation symbol Rğ‘…Ritalic_R and any tuple (a1,â€¦,ak)âˆˆRğ€subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘…ğ€(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k})\in R^{\mathbf{A}}( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A, there exists a tuple (b1,â€¦,bk)âˆˆRğsubscriptğ‘1â€¦superscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘…ğ(b_{1},\ldots,b^{k})\in R^{\mathbf{B}}( italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆˆ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where hâ¢(ai)=biâ„subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–h(a_{i})=b_{i}italic_h ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all aisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on which hâ„hitalic_h is defined.

As we mentioned, the definition of this game is based on the existential kğ‘˜kitalic_k-pebble game introduced by Kolaitis and VardiÂ [18, 20]. In the existential kğ‘˜kitalic_k-pebble game, the number of pebbles that the Spoiler may use is bounded by kğ‘˜kitalic_k, and the Duplicator need only must ensure that hâ„hitalic_h is a partial homomorphism. A close relationship between this game and bounded treewidth has been identifiedÂ [2].

Theorem 3.1

[2] Let ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A and ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B be relational structures. For all kâ‰¥2ğ‘˜2k\geq 2italic_k â‰¥ 2, the following are equivalent.

  • â€¢

    There is a winning strategy for the Duplicator in the existential kğ‘˜kitalic_k-pebble game on ğ€,ğğ€ğ\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B.

  • â€¢

    For all relational structures ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T}bold_T of treewidth <kabsentğ‘˜<k< italic_k, if there is a homomorphism from ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T}bold_T to ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A, then there is a homomorphism from ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T}bold_T to ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B.

To relate the game that we have defined with coverwidth, we are interested in parameterized versions of the game where the weight of the pebbles that the Spoiler has in play, is bounded by a constant kğ‘˜kitalic_k. (Here, by â€œweightâ€ we are using DefinitionÂ 4.) That is, the weight of the ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A-elements that have pebbles, is bounded by the constant kğ‘˜kitalic_k. We call this the existential kğ‘˜kitalic_k-cover game. We now formalize the notion of a winning strategy for the Duplicator in the existential kğ‘˜kitalic_k-cover game. Note that when hâ„hitalic_h is a partial function, we use ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â¢(h)ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â„\mathsf{dom}(h)sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) to denote the domain of hâ„hitalic_h.

Definition 9

A winning strategy for the Duplicator in the existential kğ‘˜kitalic_k-cover game on relational structures ğ€,ğğ€ğ\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B is a non-empty set Hğ»Hitalic_H of projective homomorphisms (from ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A to ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B) having the following two properties.

  1. 1.

    (the â€œforthâ€ property) For every hâˆˆHâ„ğ»h\in Hitalic_h âˆˆ italic_H and ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A-element aâˆ‰ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â¢(h)ğ‘ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â„a\notin\mathsf{dom}(h)italic_a âˆ‰ sansserif_dom ( italic_h ), if ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â¢(h)âˆª{a}ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â„ğ‘\mathsf{dom}(h)\cup\{a\}sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) âˆª { italic_a } has weight â‰¤kabsentğ‘˜\leq kâ‰¤ italic_k, then there exists a projective homomorphism hâ€²âˆˆHsuperscriptâ„â€²ğ»h^{\prime}\in Hitalic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_H extending hâ„hitalic_h with ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â¢(hâ€²)=ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â¢(h)âˆª{a}ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†superscriptâ„â€²ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â„ğ‘\mathsf{dom}(h^{\prime})=\mathsf{dom}(h)\cup\{a\}sansserif_dom ( italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) âˆª { italic_a }.

We have the following analog of Theorem 3.1.

Theorem 3.2

Let ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A and ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B be relational structures. For all kâ‰¥1ğ‘˜1k\geq 1italic_k â‰¥ 1, the following are equivalent.

  • â€¢

    There is a winning strategy for the Duplicator in the kğ‘˜kitalic_k-cover game on ğ€,ğğ€ğ\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B.

  • â€¢

    For all relational structures ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T}bold_T of coverwidth â‰¤kabsentğ‘˜\leq kâ‰¤ italic_k, if there is a homomorphism from ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T}bold_T to ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A, then there is a homomorphism from ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T}bold_T to ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B.

TheoremÂ 3.2 can be easily applied to show that in an instance ğ€,ğğ€ğ\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B of the CSP, if the left-hand side structure has coverwidth bounded by kğ‘˜kitalic_k, then deciding if there is a homomorphism from ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A to ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B is equivalent to deciding the existence of a Duplicator winning strategy in the existential kğ‘˜kitalic_k-cover game.

Theorem 3.3

Let ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A be a relational structure having coverwidth â‰¤kabsentğ‘˜\leq kâ‰¤ italic_k, and let ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B be an arbitrary relational structure. We will use this theorem in the next section to develop tractability results. Although we use TheoremÂ 3.2 to derive this theorem, we would like to emphasize that the full power of TheoremÂ 3.2 is not needed to derive it, as pointed out in the proof.

Proof

If there is a homomorphism from ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A to ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B, the Duplicator can win by always setting pebbles according the homomorphism. The other direction is immediate from TheoremÂ 3.2 (note that we only need the forward implication and ğ“=ğ€ğ“ğ€\mathbf{T}=\mathbf{A}bold_T = bold_A). âˆ

4 The Algorithmic Viewpoint

The previous section introduced the existential kğ‘˜kitalic_k-cover game. We showed that deciding a CSP instance of bounded coverwidth is equivalent to deciding if the Duplicator has a winning strategy in the existential kğ‘˜kitalic_k-cover game. In this section, we show that the latter propertyâ€“the existence of a Duplicator winning strategyâ€“can be decided algorithmically in polynomial time. To this end, it will be helpful to introduce the notion of a compact winning strategy.

    For all hâˆˆHâ„ğ»h\in Hitalic_h âˆˆ italic_H, ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â¢(h)ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â„\mathsf{dom}(h)sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) is a kğ‘˜kitalic_k-union (over ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A).

  2. 2.

    For every hâˆˆHâ„ğ»h\in Hitalic_h âˆˆ italic_H and for every kğ‘˜kitalic_k-union Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U (over ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A), there exists hâ€²âˆˆHsuperscriptâ„â€²ğ»h^{\prime}\in Hitalic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_H with ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â¢(hâ€²)=Uğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†superscriptâ„â€²ğ‘ˆ\mathsf{dom}(h^{\prime})=Usansserif_dom ( italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_U such that for every vâˆˆğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â¢(h)âˆ©ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â¢(hâ€²)ğ‘£ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â„ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†superscriptâ„â€²v\in\mathsf{dom}(h)\cap\mathsf{dom}(h^{\prime})italic_v âˆˆ sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) âˆ© sansserif_dom ( italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), hâ¢(v)=hâ€²â¢(v)â„ğ‘£superscriptâ„â€²ğ‘£h(v)=h^{\prime}(v)italic_h ( italic_v ) = italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v ).

Proposition 3

We have just shown that deciding if there is a winning strategy, in an instance of the existential kğ‘˜kitalic_k-cover game, is equivalent to deciding if there is a compact winning strategy. We now use this equivalence to give a polynomial-time algorithm for deciding if there is a winning strategy.

Theorem 4.1

For all kâ‰¥1ğ‘˜1k\geq 1italic_k â‰¥ 1, there exists a polynomial-time algorithm that, given a pair of relational structures ğ€,ğğ€ğ\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B, decides whether or not there is a winning strategy for the Duplicator in the existential kğ‘˜kitalic_k-cover game on ğ€,ğğ€ğ\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B.

Proof

By PropositionÂ 3, it suffices to give a polynomial-time algorithm that decides if there is a compact winning strategy. It is straightforward to develop such an algorithm based on the definition of compact winning strategy. Let Hğ»Hitalic_H be the set of all functions hâ„hitalic_h such that ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â¢(h)ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â„\mathsf{dom}(h)sansserif_dom ( italic_h ) is a kğ‘˜kitalic_k-union (over ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A) and such that hâ„hitalic_h is a projective homomorphism from ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A to ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B. Iteratively perform the following until no changes can be made to Hğ»Hitalic_H: for every function hâˆˆHâ„ğ»h\in Hitalic_h âˆˆ italic_H and every kğ‘˜kitalic_k-union Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U, check to see if there is hâ€²âˆˆHsuperscriptâ„â€²ğ»h^{\prime}\in Hitalic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_H such that the second property (of compact winning strategy) is satisfied; if not, remove hâ„hitalic_h from Hğ»Hitalic_H. Throughout the algorithm, we have maintained the invariant that any compact winning strategy must be a subset of Hğ»Hitalic_H. Hence, if when the algorithm terminates Hğ»Hitalic_H is empty, then there is no compact winning strategy. And if Hğ»Hitalic_H is non-empty when the algorithm terminates, Hğ»Hitalic_H is clearly a compact winning strategy.

The number of kğ‘˜kitalic_k-unions (over ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A) is polynomial in the number of tuples in ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A. Also, for each kğ‘˜kitalic_k-union Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U, the number of projective homomorphisms hâ„hitalic_h with ğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â¢(h)=Uğ–½ğ—ˆğ—†â„ğ‘ˆ\mathsf{dom}(h)=Usansserif_dom ( italic_h ) = italic_U from ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A to ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B is polynomial in the number of tuples in ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B. Hence, the size of the original set Hğ»Hitalic_H is polynomial in the original instance. Since in each iteration an element is removed from Hğ»Hitalic_H, the algorithm terminates in polynomial time. âˆ

The algorithm we have just described in the proof of TheoremÂ 4.1 may appear to be quite specialized. However, we now show that essentially that algorithm can be viewed as a general inference procedure for CSP instances in the vein of existing consistency algorithms. In particular, we give a general algorithm called projective kğ‘˜kitalic_k-consistency for CSP instances that, given a CSP instance, performs inference and outputs a more constrained CSP instance having exactly the same satisfying assignments as the original. On a CSP instance ğ€,ğğ€ğ\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B, the algorithm might detect an inconsistency, by which we mean that it detects that there is no homomorphism from ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A to ğğ\mathbf{B}bold_B. If it does not, then it is guaranteed that there is a winning strategy for the Duplicator.

The first property is straightforward to verify. For the second property, observe that, each time a tuple is removed from ğâ€²superscriptğâ€²\mathbf{B}^{\prime}bold_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the set of satisfying assignments is preserved. By using the results presented in this section thus far, it is easy to show that CSP instances of bounded coverwidth are tractable. Define the coverwidth of a CSP instance ğ€,ğğ€ğ\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B}bold_A , bold_B to be the coverwidth of ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A. Let ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–¯â¢[ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—â‰¤k]ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–¯delimited-[]ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—ğ‘˜\mathsf{CSP}[\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k]sansserif_CSP [ sansserif_coverwidth â‰¤ italic_k ] be the restriction of the CSP to all instances of coverwidth less than or equal to kğ‘˜kitalic_k.

Theorem 4.3

For all kâ‰¥1ğ‘˜1k\geq 1italic_k â‰¥ 1, the problem ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–¯â¢[ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—â‰¤k]ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–¯delimited-[]ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—ğ‘˜\mathsf{CSP}[\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k]sansserif_CSP [ sansserif_coverwidth â‰¤ italic_k ] is decidable in polynomial time by the projective kğ‘˜kitalic_k-consistency algorithm. In particular, on an instance of ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–¯â¢[ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—â‰¤k]ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–¯delimited-[]ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—ğ‘˜\mathsf{CSP}[\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k]sansserif_CSP [ sansserif_coverwidth â‰¤ italic_k ], the projective kğ‘˜kitalic_k-consistency algorithm reports an inconsistency if and only if the instance is not satisfiable.

Proof

Immediate from Theorem 3.3 and the third property of Theorem 4.2. âˆ

Note that we can derive the tractability of CSP instances having bounded hypertree width immediately from TheoremÂ 4.3.

Now, given a CSP instance that is promised to have bounded coverwidth, we can use projective kğ‘˜kitalic_k-consistency to decide the instance (Theorem 4.3). This tractability result can in fact be pushed further: we can show that there is a generic polynomial-time that, given an arbitrary CSP instance, is guaranteed to decide instances of bounded coverwidth. Moreover, whenever an instance is decided to be a â€œyesâ€ instance by the algorithm, a satisfying assignment is constructed.

Theorem 5.1

Tractability.

We let ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–¯â¢[ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—â‰¤k]ğ–°ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–¯delimited-[]ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—ğ—‚ğ–½ğ—ğ—ğ‘˜\mathsf{QCSP}[\mathsf{coverwidth}\leq k]sansserif_QCSP [ sansserif_coverwidth â‰¤ italic_k ] denote the restriction of the QCSP to all instances (p,ğ€),ğğ‘ğ€ğ(p,\mathbf{A}),\mathbf{B}( italic_p , bold_A ) , bold_B where (p,ğ€)ğ‘ğ€(p,\mathbf{A})( italic_p , bold_A ) has coverwidth less than or equal to kğ‘˜kitalic_k. Theorem 5.2
